briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon, everyone. We will now begin the climate briefing for January 25, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Climate Crisis: Normalized Disasters and the Cry of Ecosystems
sections.content: In today's domestic and international news, it has become clear that the climate crisis is no longer a distant future problem, but an everyday reality threatening our lives and ecosystems. Domestically, warnings have emerged that disasters are becoming normalized, leading to a breakdown of safety nets [1], and a subtle crisis in ecosystems has been reported, such as rising global temperatures causing a decline in the quality of honey essential for monarch butterfly survival [2]. Internationally, volunteer firefighters in Nova Scotia, Canada, are on the front lines of climate change [13], and in Senegal, climate change is exacerbating historical conflicts between farmers and pastoralists [18]. As cross-country skiing in Switzerland is threatened [20], authors Barbara Kingsolver and Amitav Ghosh have sounded the alarm, emphasizing that 'climate change is change in everything,' confirming that the 'storm cloud of climate change' [21] predicted by writer John Ruskin has become a reality [22].

sections.title: âš ï¸ International Society's Climate Policy Challenges and Emerging Accountability
sections.content: Concerns are growing regarding the future outlook for global climate action, with criticisms raised that the Trump administration is undermining the foundation of climate regulations and pushing for the repeal of 'endangerment findings,' thereby accelerating the global climate crisis [7, 15]. Consequently, voices are emerging that former President Trump cannot escape responsibility for accelerating the climate crisis [7]. In the international community, arguments have been made that it is time to clarify accountability for climate change [14]. Furthermore, a review of the BBC Symphony Orchestra's climate change oratorio performance noted that while the message was present, musical elements were lacking, offering insight into the ongoing considerations regarding how to effectively convey the climate crisis message [19].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Steps Towards Carbon Neutrality and Technological Innovation, Domestically and Internationally
sections.content: Amidst these challenges, news of various domestic and international efforts and technological innovations towards carbon neutrality has been reported. Domestically, young people in Seoul are promoting carbon neutrality projects [3], and HD Hyundai Construction Equipment views 2050 carbon neutrality not as a 'slogan but survival,' seeking to expand renewable energy and eco-friendly products [4]. The activities of carbon-neutral village cooperatives are also gaining attention [5], and the Southwest region plans to lead balanced regional development as a hub for renewable energy and infrastructure [8]. Furthermore, Korea Midland Power (KOMIPO) has finalized solar power financing in Oman, establishing a bridgehead for renewable energy in the Middle East [9]. In Australia, the world's largest electric-powered 'zero-carbon ship,' measuring 130m in length, has begun trial operations, marking significant progress in the maritime transport sector [12]. In-depth discussions are also underway regarding the potential utilization of not only electricity but also thermal energy to achieve carbon neutrality [6].

sections.title: ğŸŒ Climate Change Reshaping the Global Economy and Society
sections.content: Climate change is not merely an environmental issue but is reshaping global economic and social structures. In Greenland, climate change is creating new economic opportunities alongside ecological concerns [16], and the surge in cocoa production in Ecuador clearly demonstrates how climate change is altering agricultural landscapes [17]. Domestically, discussions have begun on new social safety nets, such as the 'Haenam Typhoon Pension' to prepare for typhoon damage [10]. Internationally, attention is focused on how home insulation plans will impact the Labour Party's warm homes initiative [23], indicating active discussions on the social and economic ripple effects of climate change. The Korea Transportation Safety Authority is conducting a public vote to select vehicle models for the 2026 Vehicle Safety Assessment, exploring the direction of future mobility [11].

briefing.closing: Today's briefing has provided an overview of the severity of the climate crisis, alongside domestic and international efforts to overcome it, and the comprehensive socioeconomic changes brought about by climate change. This is a critical juncture where international responsibility and cooperation for climate action are more urgent than ever, demanding wise responses for a sustainable future. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.description: A public vote is underway for citizens to directly select the car models that will undergo safety evaluations, including crash tests. The Korea Transportation Safety Authority (TS) announced on the 25th that it will conduct a nationwide public vote until the 31st to select the target models for the '2026 Korea New Car Assessment Program (KNCAP)'. The vehicle safety evaluation is conducted annually by the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport and the TS Vehicle Safety Research Institute on new cars sold domestically, assessing crash and accident prevention safety, electric vehicle Â·Â·Â·

summary.phenomenon: The Korea Transportation Safety Authority (TS) is conducting a public vote from the 25th to the 31st to select the target vehicle models for the '2026 Korea New Car Assessment Program (KNCAP)'.

articles.description: Australia-built electric propulsion vessel 'Hull 096' boasts battery capacity over 400 times that of an electric car. Incat Tasmania's electric propulsion vessel 'Hull 096' is undergoing sea trials. (Image provided by Incat) The world's largest electric propulsion vessel, 'Hull 096', has commenced sea trials. Measuring 130 meters in length, this vessel is expected to be deployed on a regular route connecting countries in South America this year, operating with zero carbon emissions.

summary.phenomenon: The world's largest electric propulsion vessel, 'Hull 096', measuring 130 meters in length and built in Australia, has commenced sea trials. This vessel possesses a battery capacity over 400 times that of an electric car.
summary.outlook: This vessel is expected to be deployed on a regular route connecting South American countries this year, operating with zero carbon emissions.
